conbody.p: A corpus of Dita documents consists of one or more topics bound together by one or more Bookmaps
Dita encourages the reuse of topics within bookmaps to facilitate the sharing of information.
A measure of this sharing in action can be obtained by dividing the number of topics reused by the total number of topics referenced within the document corpus to obtain the topicReuseRatio.
Specifically: Count the number of topics in the document corpus and record this as numberOfTopics.
Then: count the number of topicref s in all the Bookmaps in the corpus and record this as numberOfUses.

To obtain the topicReuseRatio for a document we divide the number of uses numberOfUses by the number of numberOfTopics. If no topics are reused this will produce the number one as both numbers will be the same. More topic reuse will increase the topicReuseRatio.

To indicate the amount of reuse more accurately, let us rebase it to zero
by subtracting one so thatthe scheme starts at zero.

The ratio is chosen to exhibit larger numbers for corpii that have more tooic reusue in them. It is easy to abuse this ratio by adding lots of refences to an empty topic. However, such transgressions are easy to detect in an automated manner and so can be discounted.
Typical word Documents have a topicReuseRatio of about 0.1.
Dita documents written by a beginner have a topicReuseRatio of about 0.5.

More advanced users of Dita tend to exhibit a higher topicReuseRatio
in their work, usually exceeding 3.0 but often going much higher. Imagine for example several bookmaps describing bathroom fittings with documents aimed at customers, sales people, management, building contractors, product engineers, architects, building code inspectors. Some of the topics such as safety are applicable to all audiences, others such as color schemes
might be of less interest to inspectors than to customeres.

Xref reports the topicReuseRatio in the counts/
as topic_reuse_ratio.txt
